review.title: False arrhythmia alarm reduction in the intensive care unit
review.abstract: Research has shown that false alarms constitute more than 80% of the alarms triggered in the intensive care unit (ICU). The high false arrhythmia alarm rate has severe implications such as disruption of patient care, caregiver alarm fatigue, and desensitization from clinical staff to real life-threatening alarms. A method to reduce the false alarm rate would therefore greatly benefit patients as well as nurses in their ability to provide care. We here develop and describe a robust false arrhythmia alarm reduction system for use in the ICU. Building off of work previously described in the literature, we make use of signal processing and machine learning techniques to identify true and false alarms for five arrhythmia types. This baseline algorithm alone is able to perform remarkably well, with a sensitivity of 0.908, a specificity of 0.838, and a PhysioNet/CinC challenge score of 0.756. We additionally explore dynamic time warping techniques on both the entire alarm signal as well as on a beat-by-beat basis in an effort to improve performance of ventricular tachycardia, which has in the literature been one of the hardest arrhythmias to classify. Such an algorithm with strong performance and efficiency could potentially be translated for use in the ICU to promote overall patient care and recovery.

sections.heading: 2.4 Evaluation metrics
sections.text: In order to evaluate the performance of the basic algorithm and the DTW approaches, we calculate and compare several quantitative indicators with those of existing algorithms. The evaluation indicators include sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), negative predictive value (NPV), F1 (the harmonic mean of PPV and sensitivity) and the scoring indicator from the 2015 PhysioNet / CinC Challenge, calculated as: Score = TP + TNTP + TN + FP + 5 х FN (2), where TP, TN, FP and FN are the number of true positives, true negatives, false positives and false negatives [2]. Rating indicators are calculated for all five arrhythmia types and individually for each arrhythmia class.

sections.heading: 3 RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
sections.text: We aim to minimize the rate of false alarms in the ICU while introducing a near zero number of false negatives. We implement an existing algorithm to address this problem and aim to improve performance in ventricular tachycardia, in particular through dynamic time-warping techniques. We expect the performance of the new implementation of the base algorithm to be comparable to the results of Plesinger et al. [7], with potentially improved performance indicators resulting from time-warping techniques.

sections.heading: 3.1 Baseline algorithm
sections.text: Overall, with the improvement outlined above, the baseline algorithm was able to achieve a sensitivity of 0.908 and a specificity of 0.838 for all arrhythmia types investigated here, resulting in a Physionet / CinC Challenge score of 0.756. Furthermore, the improved baseline algorithm was able to reduce the false alarm rate to 9.9% and at the same time introduce 3.6% false negatives. sections.heading: 3.3 Feasibility for real-time algorithm
sections.text: In terms of runtime, DTW 94 "s baseline algorithm and beat-by-beat approach are probably the most practicable for a real-time challenge where decisions about true and false alarms need to be made quickly. In terms of adaptability and expandability, DTW 67" s beat-by-beat approach with a ventricular beat bank suffers somewhat because the ventricular beats in the ventricular beat bank need to be manually identified and added to the bank. In addition, the ventricular beat-bank approach could suffer significantly as the number of different types and morphologies of ventricular beats increases while the number of beats in the ventricular beat bank remains constant. Semi-monitored parametric methods for identifying ventricular beats could alleviate this problem to some extent [6]. Thus, the improved baseline algorithm would perform best as a lead-in-time setting.

sections.heading: 4 CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We describe and implement a system to reduce the false alarm rate in the ICU by analyzing multimodal data using signal processing and machine learning methods. We build on previous work to build an improved baseline algorithm based on multimodal data to achieve a general sensitivity of 0.908, and a PhysioNet / CinC score of 0.756. referenceMentions.context: False alarms are extremely common in the intensive care unit (ICU), and research has found that in certain settings, only 17% of alarms are classified as clinically relevant [8].

The resulting constant barrage of clinical alarms can lead to disruption of care and caregiver alarm fatigue, resulting in slower response time to real lifethreatening events due to desensitization of clinical staff [4].
Thus, systems to reduce false alarm rates in the ICU have much potential to improve standard of care in the ICU and overall patient outcomes [3].
A number of algorithms to try to reduce the false arrhythmia alarm rate have been investigated and developed to varying degrees of success in recent years [7].
In particular, as part of the 2015 PhysioNet/Computing in Cardiology (CinC) Challenge, participants were invited to specifically address the issue of high false alarm rates in the ICU [7].
